reviews.review_text: Rating: 8/10  Overview: Top down Hack and Slash  The Good  +The game has 6 main characters: paladin, ranger, wizard, warlock, priest and thief. Each character has their own unique combat traits, skills and passive abilities. Playing with different characters to see how they play differently is part of the fun. Collecting gold throughout the game allows you to unlock new skills and abilities from shop vendors.   +The main game is split into 4 acts. Each act contains 3 dungeon levels. Each level contains a seal that you have to unlock to fight the boss for each act. Every level on the dungeon contains secrets and hidden passage ways. Exploring and finding these secrets is rewarding.  +The bonus campaign is handled differently and just as fun. This bonus campaign is much less linear and allows you travel back to previously visited levels, it is also much harder. Sadly, you cannot transfer your main character to this campaign.   +The game pushes a ton of enemies on screen. The pixelated graphics work really well in that regard.   +Cool boss battles  +Steam workshop support means there are plenty of custom maps you can play  +The multiplayer community is still active and I was always able to find and join a game easily.    The Average  -difficulty achievements do not stack  The Bad  - The game can get very repetitive at times. Unlike most ARPG's this game doesn't have a robust character creation making things somewhat boring after awhile. This game has no loot providing little incentive to kill all the enemies. I found myself playing in short sessions simply because the game play formula started to wear thin the farther I went along.   Conclusion  This is a game you play to try out different characters that fit your play style and then kill wave after wave of enemy as you progress through the level. If that excites you then this is a game for you. This game is ARPG lite and for the most part, works very well but if you are looking for something with a bit more depth you may be disappointed with what this game has to offer.

Overall I would recommend this game to play with somebody, and wouldn't recommend it much for the solo play.  8.5/10.

Brilliantly done retro Action RPG that is a lot of fun to play with friends. The goal of the game is to get through a number of sprawling dungeons, filled with enemies, loot, obscure secrets and boss fights, with a big emphasis on combat and looting.  The gameplay reminds me a lot of Zelda: A Link To The Past in the way you control your character, though instead of fighting one and one enemy, here it is all about fighting stupidly huge hordes of enemies and getting the highest kill combos possible to activate special abilities, while also dodging a large ammount of projectiles, which lend itself really well to this type of gameplay due to it's smooth controlls. However, you do want to play it with friends, as there appears to be little to no difficulty scaling according to the ammount of players, and you are gonna die a lot if you don't have some friends with you to help.  Something also worth noting is that despite it's retro look and game style, it avoids going into Rougelike territory and instead opts with premade maps and a extra lives system, which I like myself as I prefer a well designed static map and more tries per game, though if you want your experience to be randomized you might have to look elsewhere for that. However, the game comes bundled with a map editor so you can make your own dungeons to spice things up after beating the official campaign.   It's a bit repetitive, but as a pure multiplayer game it's entertaining, challenging without being unfair most of the time and sports a great retro look and feel without having that limit the quality of the gameplay itself. Worth checking out for sure along with some friends.

I still haven't been able to finish this game all the way through, but I have had one hell of a good time so far. Having several classes to choose from makes each runthrough all the more different and having those vendors set up all around the dungeons makes for a seemingly endless number of possibilities of how your run will turn out. Part of me wishes that it was a randomly generated dungeon each time, because I think it would work very well for this game, but it seems to be fine how it is, the dungeons are confusing enough, random generation would make me go insane. And from what I take from the story, you have been separated from your group due to a collapsed bridge and you're forced to traverse the monster dwelling dungeon to reach your goal. Gold, mana crystals, food, keys, and other items will aide you throughout your quest. Fight monsters/bosses, solve puzzles, upgrade your character, you name it! All can be done in the game, Hammerwatch.  There are quite a few games nowadays that use pixel-art to stylize their games, but in many occasions, it's not never well done and looks similar to something drawn in MSpaint. HOWEVER this is not one of those games. Whoever made this game should be patted on the back and given a firm handshake for the look of this game. This game is dang beatiful, if I may say so myself. The use of shaders is also very well done. The realistic lighting, bloom/glow effects, dark and colorised lighting makes it just that much better and works well to set the general dark mood of the game.  One issue that I have run into is the saving. You save by standing on a checkpoint and it overwrites your previous save to one designated run slot. If you died, you can re-load the save and you'll start back from the last time you reached a checkpoint. BUT, this can be extremely aggrivating if you save at a checkpoint with low health. You'll continue to start back with that same amount of health until you find some food, and if you're in a position where there's basically none, you'll have to die and die and die and die untill eventually you weasel your way through the dungeon on scraps that the enemies drop.   Another issue I've found is the difficulty. Bear in mind I was on the Medium difficulty and you can set it to Easier in-game, I'm just noting my experience. After a few floors have passed you'll find yourself being bombarded with constantly respawning enemies at 'nests'. They spawn so quickly that it's inevitable that you're going to take a few hits while trying to take it out. This is find for one or two nests, but when there are like 15 in one room, you're basically ♥♥♥♥ed. And I was on Medium, I couldn't imagine doing that on hard mode. Other than those blasted nests, the enemies are pretty fairly balanced, you got slow moving large-healthed monsters, fast moving low-healthed, very slow moving but capable of shooting projectiles. Difficult at first but once you get the hang of it, you'll be fine.  Other than these two extremely miniscule issues, this game is perfect. I highly recommend picking it up at full price or on sale.

I give this game a thumbs up because I do not consider it a BAD game. That said, I am not especially satisfied with it, and after playing a few hours last night and completing about half of it, I do not intend to play it again. I guess rather than 'good' or 'bad', I would use the word 'standard' to describe this game. It is just a remarkably ordinary, run-of-the-mill game to me. It seems well polished, has fairly pleasant music, but nothing really sets it apart or makes it special.  I killed hundreds upon hundreds of identical enemies in rooms that all kind of felt the same. The game warns you in the beginning that it's especially difficult, but it took around an hour, maybe more, before I even took a single hit (normal difficulty). The two bosses I encountered were 'difficult', in the sense that they did hit me a fair bit, but there were so many extra lives being thrown at me that they were never actually a threat. I'd enter the boss fight with ten lives, lose two or three of them to the boss, and then gain five as a reward.  The game seemed alright when I started, but after a while I found myself just waiting for it to be over. I just spent way too much time essentially repeating the same fight over and over. Stand still and shoot into a crowd of 100 skeletons until they're gone. Move to the next room. Repeat.  I'd give this game like a 6/10 rating. Not what I consider a bad game, as it seems to be polished and do what the devs wanted it to. But not an especially good game either, as what it does is pretty unremarkable.

It was an impulse purchase, spurred on by the ability to set the game to look like it’s being played on an old CRT screen, complete with phosphor scanlines and curved edges. I’m a sucker for that stuff. The little-hero pixel artstyle is also charming enough, but trudging through the pre-built campaign just didn’t gel with me. It took too long to kill the huge hordes of monsters, to find the keys needed to open doors.  Then I tried it multiplayer, and everything fell into place. This is Gauntlet, for a new generation. Working together, covering each other’s backs, or accidentally killing your partners by triggering traps - it’s a blast. Hammerwatch is an incredibly reserved game design. There are four classes, each unique and upgradeable with new attacks you buy from vendors across the maps, but nothing carries over into a new game. It’s a bit one-shot, and might change as the game evolves since it’s still in a bit of a “beta” state.  Multiplayer works local, LAN and online, and loading a savegame for an online campaign in progress requires a bit of finagling. but it does work. Likely too simplistic for most, Hammerwatch is an acquired taste. But with the right friends, it’s a kind of magic straight out of 1985.

It definitely plays a lot like 8bit Gauntlet, which was clearly the developer's intention given that the bonus stages are taken right out of 8bit Gauntlet, but significantly fleshed out. They've nixed that game's 'food' life bar, thankfully, and added RPG elements to let you improve your damage, range, dmg mitigation, regen, etc. You 'save keys to open doors,' though here there are 3 different color keys to open their respective doors. Collect treasure to purchase your upgrades from vendors. Loot is shared and one class is a healer, so cooperation is easier done here than in 8bit Gauntlet. There are also boss fights along the way.   The art is nice, adding variety to levels and enemies while still evoking a sense of retro gaming. Additionally, you can change the parameters. Play with limited or infinite lives, for example, so you can scale the game to a difficulty level that suits you. Essentially, any thought you might have had along the lines of, 'You know, I liked Gauntlet as a kid... but I wish they had added XYZ,' that XYZ is probably in Hammerwatch.

A secret level that's a straight-up homage to Gauntlet takes place just a few minutes before a bullet-hell boss that can be beaten with ample 1-UPs and brute force, or without taking damage with some skills and strategy after a bit of trial and error. The game is obviously a labor of love, and feels like what I hope to recapture when replaying games from my childhood. I haven't had the opportunity to play this in co-op mode, but even if you're just picking it up to solo, if you have fond memories of playing both 1943 and Gauntlet in arcades growing up, you'll find lot of familiar fun in this game.

There is no 1 million+ damage numbers here, its just you (and friends if you choose!) versus the hordes of maggots, undead, demons and whatever else the game decides to throw at you. Puzzles can be challenging and the overwhelming enemies sometimes (unfairly) punishing players. When it comes to a retro feel, something that reminds you of Diablo 2 or even Realm of The Mad Gods, Hammerwatch does exactly that. I followed this game from the Steam Greenlight forums and even tested the beta. From the beginning I knew that this was something I wanted to get my hands on once it came out.  The game takes place inside of Castle Hammerwatch, where your goal will be to travel from down the prison up to the royal chambers in the top and kill the evil dragon. You play as either a Paladin, Wizard, Warlock or Knight and each character has its own weapon and special ability.  Don’t be fooled, this is a serious game; and even on medium difficulty you will still have a hard time fighting through the numerous levels in each Act. The game is better played in multiplayer mode, but to be honest, good luck joining a game. For some reason I find it impossible to host a game, but I am able to join others, and this is when the game is best played.  Hammerwatch also offers a few perks, what they call “crutches” in the game if you choose to host your own single or multiplayer game. Different options allow you to make the game easier or a little harder. I suggest playing with the HP Regen and Infinite Lives crutch on when first playing, that way you can get a feel for what you’re about to be in for.  A game that is still in beta and continuously going through changes is sometimes hard to review, taking everything into consideration the game is awesome. Aside from the bunk multiplayer Hammerwatch is worth every penny. Constant battle action laced with power ups, secret passages and hidden doors makes Hammerwatch a soon to be classic and a necessity in any gamers library.  Graphics: 7/10 Playability: 8/10 Story: 4/10 Challenge: 8/10 Replay Value: 6/10

The Good:  Hammerwatch inherits a lot of the fun of Gauntlet in that classic hack 'n slash style -- from ravenous swarms of (wo)man-eating eyeballs to the shambling eldritch fury of unholy liches, there're plenty of enemies to wallop, ignite, poison, and bullseye. With up to four player local co-op available, with mappable control sets for both keyboard and controller inputs, the game's extremely friendly and social to the game-loving crew that remembers the heydays of couch co-op. (You can play online, too -- no worries.) The visuals are simple, retro-ish, and can even be edited to make your screen look more like a standard def 16-bit game (if you're into that sort of thing).  For anyone concerned about how the game runs: it's smooth. You can turn down the settings significantly if your computer's not exactly top-of-the-line, and you'll likely do just fine. (My poor PC's been struggling for some time now to run too much of anything, but Hammerwatch doesn't hiccup on me once I cut back on some of the graphical bells and whistles.) The devs did a great job of giving the player a game that can be customized to fit a variety of play needs/experiences, and the ability to strip down the graphical demands to smooth out the game is one example of many.  The editor is great. Sprites are PNGs, their basic coding's XML, and the level editor itself is a pretty easy-to-learn GUI. There's some scripting involved for more advanced functions, but anyone who's experimented with modding in the past'll find a pretty simple, quick-to-get-into editor for the game. (In particular, cosmetic changes to the game are a snap.)  The Bad:  This game is fun, but there's just not a ton of it. You get a campaign with the game itself that'll take you through a handful of dungeons and bosses. They're not procedurally generated, so once you've played the game, you've played the game -- return trips are going to be much of the same. (Of course, you get four classes to experiment with, and three possible difficulty settings.) There's a survival mode that can add some fun to the game, but the lack of content sadly holds Hammerwatch back from having its real potential realized.  The community's doing what it can to add to the game -- like I said, the devs have put together a solid set of editing tools that can allow for plenty of ambitious modders to take the game the extra mile. However, that community's not a particularly big one. (I suppose this is a call to action, then: buy the game, and start making new campaigns for it! Something something about a rising tide lifting all boats...)  Also, the single-player's a little boring. It's not really the game's 'thing' -- it's a party-based game -- but you can wander the dungeons alone if you're into that sort of thing. You just might not have quite as much fun...  TL;DR:  Buy this game. Give it a playthrough with your friends. If you're really a mensch, build a campaign or make some cool sprites for the community. This game deserves more publicity and more people contributing to it content-wise. (And the devs deserve your coin.) It's got some draw-backs, but, in terms of fun-versus-price, you're going to get a good investment return out of it.

The skills for each class fit each class nicely and make each class play very, very differently, which is great for variety and the team aspect of the game. These skills allow you to grow you character as you see fit; you can do more damage, do that damage more often or upgrade/purchase unique skills, or buy skills that allow you to be more durable in different ways. These skills play to each class' particular strengths, and as a result, they are all pretty balanced, but there are also weaknesses that can be overcome with time or teammates. It's a simple setup and skill tree, and it works extremely well for character balance.  The music is nice, but I ended up turning it off in favor of my own playlist, but aside from that, there really are no discernable negatives to this game.   I think this game was made by gamers, for gamers, and incorporates a lot of good ideas into a very streamlined, good product.  Highly recommend.

Although I admit that it is not nearly as bad as that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ The binding of Isaac... It still crashed on me a couple of times. But thankfully my saves weren't corrupted(as some of my friends').  PROS: -It is kinda funny to play in a group. Expecially if the other palyers aren't that experienced with gaming(since you could better play diablo or anything other). Hammerwatch is a hack 'n' slash dungeon crawler that starts off pretty strong for the first couple floors. The combat is satisfying and has a nice feel to it, while the levels are sprawling and labyrinthian with lots of secrets scattered about. I'm a fan of the detailed pixel art style and the soundtrack is fun and fits the game nicely. The keyboard controls felt way too clunky, but using a 360 pad instead made for a much smoother experience.  The big problem with the game is that after those first couple floors, I started to realize how tedious and repetitive everything was becoming. The basic structure boils down to going from room to room, running past enemies to aggro them and bunch them together, killing off these groups of enemies, then going to the next room and doing it all over again. New enemies are introduced along the way but they're essentially re-skinned versions of old ones. Room layouts also vary and there are the occasional traps that make planning your attacks more interesting, but other than that, there's so little difference between an encounter on the third floor and one on the tenth. The floors themselves are huge in size, which I like, but this can be a double-edged sword since they start to drag on after a while. There is some joy in taking down dozens/hundreds of enemies at once and racking up a huge combo, but that joy is almost entirely gone after doing it hundreds of times repeatedly.  I also wasn't a fan of the fact that in order to reach the legitimate ending, you'll need to collect 12 wooden planks along the way. There's never any suggestion that these planks were anything other than optional, so I never sought them out. And since you can't go back to previous floors after completing boss fights, once you miss them, they're gone. It felt like a cheap tactic and left me somewhat disappointed.  Hammerwatch has a few things going for it and some really nice ideas. Unfortunately, the monotony of fighting large hordes over and over in the same manner overshadows a lot of them. Instead of being a fun experience, it turns into a grind and stays that way until the end.

It looks great, the music is absolutely awesome, controls are nice, there's good atmosphere. A lot of elements are on the right place but it fails to give me an engaging experience, and the main reason for that is the lack of depth in the game.   You'll start playing the game with, for example, a wizard. So you'll start to walk around, shoot fireballs, collect coins and keys. And you'll keep doing that forever with very little variation. Very rarely you'll update your character to change some stats that you'll hardly notice. Enemies are all more or less the same thing. It's not very challenging, the few times I die was because I got bored and reckless. Your only concern is with what's on screen at the moment, which always require the exact same strategy, and occasionally backtracking.  From the top of my head, some things that could help this game out are management of resources, the good old levelling system, different abilities, (more) different enemies that require different strategies etc. There's a good reason these things keep showing up in games, they add a whole level of gameplay the player needs to be aware of, it adds a layer of complexity. The player is not only moving and shooting, he's always thinking about these other layers, and that influences how he plays the game. Too many moving parts and the game becomes overwhelming, too few and it lacks depth which is the case with hammerwatch.  On a side note, I only played the single player campaign and I'm starting to get the impression that the game was intended as a coop experience. This could explain the simplicity, as it makes the game more casual and easy to play with friends without any prior skill.
